comments.text:
I see the problems in both trains.
His is a generalization which may or may not be correct.
Yours is a generalization that because you don't accept his statement it 
has therefor not been proved.
His question was not "loaded" because it didn't coerce you to give a 
particular response.
If you simply responded, "No, I don't. Please explain.", then it would be 
up to him to offer evidence. If he couldn't, then you would be justified in 
calling him a blowhard.
However, calling him a blowhard without even evaluating what evidence he 
might have makes you the blowhard.
Therein lies the genesis of my "retort" regarding thinking one is thinking 
when one is only thinking one is thinking.
comments.author: Liberallez

comments.text:

 Yes or no will imply something that has nothing to do with the question."

The basic problem is greed, which has at its root selfishness. Big greedy 
conglomerates are not necessarily greedier than Joe Businessman, but the 
big conglomerates can afford to pay lobbyists, who pay politicians to 
decide in the big conglomerate's favor. Joe Businessman can't compete, 
because lobbyists lobby for tougher and costlier regulations designed to 
restrain small business, while simultaneously unleashing big business. 
Conglomerates become corporate fascists, controlling a government which 
becomes socialist, the monopoly gets bigger, government gets bigger, and 
the ones who get fucked are the general public, time and time again. Uncle 
Sam doesn't even have the courtesy to use KY jelly, they just bend you over 
and give you the shaft, because they figure that they are so big, and you 
are so small, that there's nothing you can do about it, but they figure 
wrong. You can fight back. You can declare personal sovereignty. You can 
join together with other individuals and tell Uncle Sam to go choke on a 
turd. More and more folks are doing it every day. You need to realize that 
we outnumber the corporate fascists and the social communists, we outnumber 
the suits, we outnumber the cops, we are the backbone of society, and if we 
all unite and stand in unison against the monster, we will prevail. The 
difficult part is getting everyone to agree. You can only educate those who

top_comment.author: Woozler554

top_comment.text:
What this argument boils down to is trust. If you trust the government more 
that private corporation, you'll support net neutrality. If you trust 
private corporations more than the government, you'll be opposed to it. I 
personally trust the government more, so I'm excited about the FCC ruling. 
Feel free to disagree with me. If you trust private corporations more, 
fine, that's your right. But let's stop acting like the people you disagree 
with on this issue are "wrong." They just trust different people more than 
you do, be it corporations or government.﻿
top_comment.author: Corey Lando

comments.text:
+Corey Lando False equivalence/Occam's Razor fallacy. The government in 
this case (FCC) wouldn't have any more access to our personal data/data 
cables than they already do, they would just be mitigating a monopoly 
(which is inefficient economically).

Objectively, by some value (be it personal liberty or efficient allocation 
of market funds) that can be calculated (if only in terms of comparison), 
one of the positions CAN be wrong.


"trust" is a truly subjective issue, which is probably why you revert to it 
as a way of obscuring the measurable claims being made.

comments.text:
Why would someone trust a private company? Their interest come first and if 
they're monopolies, they won't really prioritise the interests of their 
customers. You can just say to them "we'll protest and not buy your 
products if you don't prioritise our interests"

This is just futile since the company would probably just move to another 
country and keep doing business there.

The power of the government however is dependant on the people. People can 
just vote who they want and if the government doesn't prioritise the 
interests of the people, they won't get voted. Also, people in the 
government often have conflicting interests so the president doesn't have 
full power that people seem to think. The president is not a monarch...

Compared to a company where the CEO has most of the power since after all, 
the CEO is probably the founder..

top_comment.author: Dan Haiduc

comments.text:
+Dan Haiduc 1. the problem with those "special rates" is it trickles down 
to the consumers, Netflix paying that fine translates to netflix bumping up 
their rates to compensate for the resources lost by greedy ISP charging 
those "special rates".

2. No offense, i feel like youre arguing out of ignorance, so lets shift 
the discussion a little bit. You say Net neutrality legislation (which is 
just returning to the status quo but i digress..) is red tape and another 
hoop that business have to go through to do business legally. 

So...tell me what exactly in net neutrality prevents business from 
thriving. Dont reply with massive generalizations (though i understand some 
generalization/simplification is needed for this discussion) or ideological 
rhetoric. I want specific points in the net neutrality regulation both past 
and current iteration that you consider "red tape" and why.

comments.author: Dan Haiduc

comments.text:
+SonYouDone Net neutrality is exactly red tape in disguise. It's another 
hoop you have to jump if you want to do business legally, another item on 
the big list, another burden on everyone.
This could be solved by competition between companies, and "common sense" 
could be proven wrong more easily than changing laws - the simple failing 
of companies.

Perhaps some net-prioritization is okay, but a balance has not been found 
(again due to lack of competition). Banning it altogether is a primitive 
and populist approach.

It's like banning negotiation. I don't see why an ISP can't demand special 
rates for very high bandwidths, or even to specific customers.

breaking patent laws or something.
comments.author: Dan Haiduc

comments.text:

comments.author: Stephen Miller

comments.text:

We get your ideology and its important we cut and try to reduce the red

comments.author: SonYouDone

comments.text:
+Dan Haiduc Then lets assume, no matter how improbable, you somehow make a 
profit in that very shaddy business of sharing your internet. The amount of 
money youll have to borrow to combine with your profits to build that 
infrastructure will literally put you in debt for years. Which isnt bad, 
ater all, most businesses arent very profitable when they start. 

So a pissed off ISP realizes youve been stealing their profits by using 
their own networks on top of jeopardizing their monopoly, so they 
retaliate. They price their plans equal or lower to yours making consumers 
decide between a well established ISP or some new kid on the block 
struggling with debt, laying down their wires etc.

He'll strip you of any profit and eventually when you give up, buy you out.

Now this is all some elaborate conjecture of what COULD happen, but i 
wanted to illustrate to you at least some of the plausible scenarios of 
just how DIFFICULT it is to create a ISP this day and age.
comments.author: SonYouDone

comments.text:
+Dan Haiduc Why it wont be profitable?

Ever wondered why the more devices connected to the router in your house, 
the slower the internet gets? Too man people demanding too much bandwidth 
from 1. the router and possibly 2. the ISP (hence in peak hours, the 
internet for your house and other residence under that ISP become a bit 
slow).

Now the ISP has the infrastructure in place to somewhat...solve that 
slowdown, while on the consumer side, not-so-much (hence your idea to 
compete locally via sharing your internet is totally flawed). Imagine 
sharing your internet with tens if not possibly 100's of people, its going 
to UNBEARABLY SLOW.

So now the consumer have a choice, stick with the discount internet thats 
god-awfully slow or pay a bit more to go back to the ISP for moderate speed 
boost. Eventually you'll have lost more customers than your gaining along 
with your money. By this point in time (lets assume the ISP doesnt realize 
what youre doing) you wont have made enough money to build funds to upgrade 
your infanstructure to actually launch a COMPETING isp.
comments.author: SonYouDone

comments.text:
Theres so many problems with that example. You're confusing Wifi Network 
with a Network Infrastructure. TO even reach profitability with that model

niche business.
comments.author: SonYouDone

comments.text:
+SonYouDone
Sorry to repeat myself, but again, here is a way of starting:
Knock at your neighbor's door and ask them if they'd like to share WiFi 
with you (at half price, say).
There, you have a network.
Then you can share one (possibly more expensive) connection on the whole 
building.
Then nothing stops you to expand.

That's all it takes. Buy bulk, sell cheaper. Perhaps pool together more 
ISPs (to have better reliability).
comments.author: Dan Haiduc

comments.text:
+Dan Haiduc Coca cola was founded at a time were few companies existed that 
produced similar products at a (nation) wide scale (unlike ISP now...), so 
they could easily start small and expand. In this day and age its next to 
impossible for companies to create their own networks, be it a cable 
company or an ISP.

Why? The sheer amount of resources needed to even START at a local level. I 
dont mean to offend you, but youre a bit ignorant on certain aspects as 
displayed in our post, this isn't equivalent to just starting a restaurant 
or some niche company, its far bigger and far far more complex.

For instance, on top of the financial resources needed to lay down the 
wires and build the infrastructure even at a local level, they have to find 
profitability. If a company releases a plan for x speed for 50$, Comcast or 
TWC can easily drop their price to make it competitive. Well, you say thats 
capitalism (which it is), but because theyre being squeezed by these giant 
tech companies, they cant make a profit and everything ends up being in 
vain. TWC swoops in to the bankrupt ISP and buys them out, further 
preserving the monopoly it previously had.

And theres so much more that goes into this, put aside the ideology for a 
second.

comments.text:
The government wouldn't be in control.  They weren't in control before, 
when Net Neutrality was the norm 10 years ago.  The reason for the debate 
now is that the ISPs got the old net neutrality rules thrown out by the 
courts.  That didn't seem to be impeding the market back then, in fact, 
there used to be a lot more ISPs than there are now.  Remember AOL?  They 
got squeezed out by the RBOCs, and their business no longer includes ISP 
services (okay, a tiny bit is left) .  The FCC tossed most of the 
anti-monopoly rules that used to be in place, and - Tada!  Monopolies!  The 
only reason that there is the discussion of "regulation" is that the ISPs 
got the courts to say that the only way that the FCC could stop monopolies 
is by regulating them like a utility.  Hence the proposals to regulate them 
like utilities.

top_comment.text:
My god.... its Mega BITS per second... not mega bytes.  Megabits are used 
when saying RATES of data (Mbps)... megabytes are used when referring to 
STORAGE of data (MB).  Why cant people get this right? its quite simple... 
small b... bits... big B... bytes.  Data rates (Mbps) Megabits per 
second...﻿
top_comment.author: Ddub1083

comments.text:
+C0missar I meant for internet connection speeds.... megabytes is not used 
as the hardware transfers bit at a time.  Also...  harddrives have 
megabytes/second because they all used to use parallel ATA cables which 
transferred BYTES at a time.  Now of course, the standard has become SATA 
which is serial but the data rates remain the same but is based on the 
earlier connectivity being specifically NOT serial.

But even still... sata cables are rated in megabits per second even if the 
read speeds of harddrives are measured as bytes per second.  Essentially 
one is measuring a PHYSICAL LAYER and the other is measuring at the 
APPLICATION layer.  The same can be seen in a internet downloader... your 
physical cables/ISP are rated at megabits per second even if your download 
application shows your speed in Megabytes per second.... again one is 
physical measurement and the other is an application measurement.
comments.author: Ddub1083

comments.text:
Although the convention is to rate in bits, bytes is just as valid.  Look 
at transfer rates of hard drives.  And the convention came originally 
because transmission is most often done serial (a bit at a time), long 
before it became a selling feature. MegaBytes is not wrong, just less 
common.
comments.author: C0missar

comments.text:
+Alex I'Anson well megabits sounds better because MB/s isnt a thing in 
realms of internet bandwidth.  again... you dont use BYTES when describing 
internet data communication speeds because it transfers bit by bit instead 
of a byte or more at a time.
comments.author: Ddub1083

comments.text:
This is true, the reason why it's so common for ISPs to use Mbps is because 
they can say a number 8 times larger than the number they would advertise 
if they used bytes. I mean, what sounds better? 60 Mbps or ~8MBps?
comments.author: Alex I'Anson

comments.text:
Well, you can have MB/s. Its just that Mbps is more commonly used for rates 
of data. Data transfer between drives is MB/s, so you can't say it's always 
Mbps for rates of data. A bit is just 1/8 of a byte: one binary digit. It's 
just a different way of measuring it. But yes, a lot of people do confuse 
them.

captions.text:
So say your local mail delivery truck stops
in front of your house, which is good because

two days ago you ordered two different books
with two-day shipping, sent out at the same

time from similar locations, and you're pretty
excited for them both.

they've already delivered like 20 packages
from today.

That's how it should work, which is why a

So say you have a one-hundred dollar a month

Comcast owns, and Comcast says, "Wow, Netflix,

they're paying for, and second, why wouldn't

It would make so much sense if Comcast's reply

But, as anyone who pays for their own internet

Second of all, we don't need the business

And Netflix did. This already happened.

Truth is, there's a lot of homes and businesses

When you order a book, the delivery truck

Here's the officially proposed rule the FCC
is considering: internet service providers

must offer some amount of access to all legal
internet things, but they can offer a "fast

lane" to certain content providers. This sounds
like maybe Comcast and Netflix collaborate

to put in a special cable all the way from
Netflix right to your home to get superfast

Netflix service, but that's not what this
fast lane is. It's not even a nice new paved

driveway. The "fast lane" means that comcast
puts a gate at the front of your driveway.

The netflix trucks are allowed in right away
because they paid off the gatekeeper. You

invite your friend over, and your friend has
to wait outside the gate for a while, even
when no one else is using your driveway.

If you want to watch netflix right now, yes,
you should be able to prioritize netflix's

vihart video, there's no technical reason

you choose.

Except they decided maybe they do want to
control what content you can choose, and the

FCC's proposed rule would make that officially
ok. Which is a huge reversal in the FCC's

position that happened when Tom Wheeler, a
former cable lobbyist, became chairman.

In 2004, the FCC basically said, "Hey, ISPs,
we made some network neutrality rules for

you, yay for open internet!" And then Comcast
started throttling bittorrent, which was against

those rules. There was a court case that Comcast
won, with the argument that the FCC couldn't

legally enforce those rules because they weren't
official enough. So the FCC created the Open

Internet Order of 2010 and voted on it and
passed it and finally, net neutrality had

real offical rules! And Verizon took the FCC
to court and was like, "Are you sure these

rules are for us? Because, they look a lot
like the rules for common carriers, and we're

not common carriers, so we're thinking the
rules don't apply to us."

And Verizon won. So if the FCC can't enforce
their own rules because ISPs aren't classified

as common carriers, a lot of people think
the FCC's next move should be to classify
ISPs as common carriers.

Basically, a common carrier can't discriminate
among the things they carry. Airlines and

Telephone Companies are common carriers, so
Apple can't pay Virgin America to not let

any Microsoft employees on their flights;
T-Mobile can't purposely drop your call while

you're trying to order a pizza if Domino's
won't pay them a cut of the order.

Up 'til recently, ISPs have been acting like
common carriers. They built their businesses

on customers' expectations that they were
common carriers, like other telecommunication

services, and with the benefit of the legal
protection given to telecommunication services,

such as not being liable for the content that
moves through their cables. In 1998 the Digital

Millenium Copyright Act thing happened, which
gave ISPs more protection from liability for

their user's actions, still back when ISPs
acted as if they were common carriers. Right

now ISPs control content without being liable
for that content.

The Telecommunications Act of 1996 helped
ISPs become big and powerful, they merged

and formed monopolies, and then they decided
it was in their best interest not to be considered

a "telecommunications service," but an "information
service," which would be less regulated, and

also have fewer protections, but since they
were now protected by the DMCA that wasn't

a problem. There were a bunch of hearings.
They won, they lost, and then in 2005 they

managed to convince 6 out of 9 judges that
even though the internet is a telecommunications

service, they also do other things, and the
Telecommunications Act that would have classified

them as a common carrier telecommunications
service does not clearly state that they have

to be classified that way even if they also
do other things.

Many net neutrality activists are asking you
to call your representative and sign petitions

and make an official comment to the FCC that
the current "fast-lane" plan is not net-neutrality,

and that the FCC should instead hold strong
to its original plan of treating ISPs like

service. If you're going to make that call
or official comment I want you to make it

with full confidence that it is right and
fair, because it's not legal to classify corporate

entities as being whatever you want just because
"yay internet."

And the internet has other problems besides

title: Net Neutrality in the US: Now What?
